title-group.article-title: Using Ducted Fuel Injection to Attenuate Soot Formation in a Mixing-Controlled Compression Ignition Engine

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC

abstract.p: Ducted fuel injection (DFI) has been proposed as a strategy to enhance the fuel/charge gas mixing within the combustion chamber of a direct-injection mixing-controlled compression ignition engine. The concept involves injecting each fuel spray through a small tube within the combustion chamber to facilitate the creation of a leaner mixture in the autoignition zone, relative to a conventional free-spray configuration (i.e., a fuel spray that is not surrounded by a duct). While previous experiments demonstrated that DFI lowers both soot incandescence and soot mass in a constant-volume combustion vessel with a single-component normal-alkane fuel (n-dodecane), this study provides the first evidence that the technology provides similar benefits in an engine application using a commercial diesel fuel containing ~30 wt% aromatics. The present study investigates the effects on engine-out emissions and efficiency with a two-orifice injector tip for charge gas mixtures containing 16 and 21 mol% oxygen. The result is that DFI is confirmed to be effective at curtailing engine-out soot emissions. It also breaks the tradeoff between emissions of soot and nitrogen oxides (NOₓ) by simultaneously attenuating soot and NOₓ with increasing dilution.

caption.p: Schematic of DFI concept on a single spray. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

Optical engine schematic. Top and bottom cameras are used for chemiluminescence and natural luminosity imaging, respectively. Only the natural luminosity (lower) camera was used for this study. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.
Experimental conditions. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.
Schematic of important DFI parameters. The duct in this image has the δ geometry. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.
Three-dimensional computer-generated rendering of two-duct assembly in the optical engine. The ducts are D2L12G3δ. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

Spatially integrated natural luminosity (SINL), apparent heat release rate (AHRR), engine-out filter smoke number (FSN), and engine-out indicated specific soot (ISSoot) emissions as functions of duct presence/configuration and intake oxygen mole fraction (XO2). © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.
NL images acquired at CA50. The same exposure, f-stop, and lens were used for all images. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

ISNOₓ, ISHC, and ISCO results. IS emissions are a quantification of the mass of the given species measured per unit energy delivered by the engine. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

In-cylinder pressure and temperature. The results shown are the averaged data for all the runs at the given condition. The D2L12G1.6δ results are not shown as they overlap with the D2L12G3δ results. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.
Load, combustion efficiency, and fuel conversion efficiency. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

Percentage of heat release from SOI to EOPMB (Q1), quasi-steady combustion from EOPMB to EOI (Q2), and EOI to EOC (Q3), ignition delay, CA50, and combustion noise for DFI vs. CDC. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

DFI breaks the soot/NOₓ tradeoff by simultaneously attenuating soot and NOₓ formation. Plot shows measured ISSoot and NOₓ data for CDC and for DFI with the D2L12G3δ configuration at 21% O₂ and 16% O₂. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.

DFI dramatically lowers soot at constant dilution and combustion phasing. Plot shows the change in IS emissions of soot, NOₓ, HC, CO, and ηf with DFI (D2L12G3δ) at 16 mol% O₂, relative to CDC at 16 mol% O₂. For a given parameter X, the bar plot shows (XDFI - XCDC)/min(XDFI,XCDC). Inset shows heat release rates for the two cases. © 2019 National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC.
